reason.tex:
%text Differentiation has the \underline\text{product rule} \[ \quad \frac{d}{dx}f(x)g(x) = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x) \]
And integration has \underline\text{integration by parts}
\[ \int f\cdot g\cdot dx = f\int g\cdot dx - \int \left[ f' \int g\cdot dx\right] dx \]
\underline\text{But what is $f(x)$ in, say, \[\int x\sin x\cdot dx\]}? Is it $f(x) = x$ or $f(x) = \sin x$?
There are no right or wrong answers. Only better ones.
\underline\text{In the table below, let $f(x)$ be the function} \underline\text{that matches first.}
% \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} \hline & \text{Meaning} & \text{Example} \\ \hline I & \text{Inverse Trig. function} & \sin^{-1} x, \tan^{-1}x \\ \hline L & \text{Logarithmic function} & \log x \\ \hline A & \text{Algebraic function} & x^2, 4x^7 \\ \hline T & \text{Trigonometric function} & \sin x, \cos x \\ \hline E & \text{Exponential function} & e^x, 7^x \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
Hence, in \[ \int x\cdot \sin x\cdot dx \] \[\qquad \underbrace{f(x) = x}_{A}\implies \underbrace{g(x) = \sin x}_{T}\] %
